summary.p: This manuscript contains a ballad (ammāṉai) written by Jesuit missionary Costanzo Giuseppe Beschi (1680-1747) around 1731. The ballad tells the story of the Catholic virgin, martyr and saint Quiteria, called in Tamil Kittēriyammāḷ; of her conversion to Christianity, and her rebellion against her Hindu father. She then flees to the mountains to escape an arranged marriage, and is eventually beheaded by the insulted groom. Beschi brought a statue of this saint to Elākkuṟicci in 1729-30, and initiated her cult: the last chapter of this ballad (putumaik kātai, folio 89r and ff.) talks about the miracles she performed there. Kittēriyammāḷ is still venerated in Tamil Nadu today, especially in the village of Kūttaṉkuḻi.

filiation.p: This texts exists in multiple manuscript and printed versions (see the bibliography below for some of the printed editions).

incipit.q:
pārmutalāyt tāṉpaṭaitta pallulakam attaṉaiyum,
vēr mutalāyp pērttacaikkum vīrat taṉikkōlāṉ,
mūvāḷ oru poruḷāy, muṟṟum pakāpporuḷāyt,
tēvāti tēvaṉavaṉ cēvaṭiyaic cērntētti
vāṉuvappa, maṇṇulakiṉ maṉṉuyirkaḷ vāḻntōṅkat,
tāṉuvantu tanta cayat taṉmaieḻuṅ kaṉṉikaiyiṉ
kātai uraittammāṉaik kaṭṭāy viḷaiyāṭap,
pētaiyarkkōr ammāṉai pētaiyum nāṉ tantiṭuvēṉ.

explicit.q: This last folio contains some stanzas from the anupallavi of a musical composition, a cintu, associated with the Kittēriyammāḷ ammāṉai. The entirety of the composition is available in the most recent printed edition of this ballad (Amaladass 2022).

extent.measure: 1 unnambered folio,85 numbered folios (1-102 with folios missing), 1 guard folio.

supportDesc.foliation: Original Tamil foliation in Tamil numerals on the left margin, starting from folio 1 until folio 102. Several folios are missing: fol. 6, fols. 9-12, fol. 18, f. 33, fols. 39-41, fol. 47, fols. 66-67, fol. 80, fol. 88, fol. 91, fol. 101.

collation.desc: The manuscript is constituted by one unit single unit containing the text, with several lacunæ) where there are missing folios. The first unnambered folio contains the title, and the verso of the final guard folio has a sticker of the BnF with the current classification (Indien 952).

supportDesc.condition: Very good state of perservation, despite some wormholes.

handNote.desc: Notwithstanding the changes in size (the writing becomes rather small at places) this seems one coherent scribal project by the same hand. The double curled kombu appears sporadically.

binding.p: No binding, one unnumbered folio with the title in the beginning, and one guard folio at the end with the BnF sticker.

origin.origDate: The ms. is dated on fol. 102r.

acquisition.p: The manuscript originally belonged to Julien Vinson (1843-1926), who donated it to the BnF.
